postsData.content:
I've seen "leaders" throw their team under the bus.

In front of coworkers.
In front of clients.
Without hesitation.

It made me realize something powerful:

If you don't defend your people,
you don't belong in leadership.

Period.

True leaders know:

 Your team's success is your success
 Their growth and achievements are your legacy
 Their trust is what makes you a leader, not your title

What does it mean to defend your team?

It's not about making excuses
or lowering your standards.

It's about:

 Fighting for their growth
 Protecting them from burnout
 Shielding them from toxic politics
 Offering support without micromanaging
 Being their voice when they're not in the room

The best leader I ever had taught me this.

When our team made mistakes, she'd say:
"That's on me. We'll fix it."

When we succeeded?
"My team did all the work. I just cleared the path."

She held us to high standards.
Gave tough feedback when needed.
But always had our backs.

Know what happened?

We gave everything for that team.
Grew faster than ever.
Achieved things we never thought possible.

Because we knew she'd be there.
Supporting. Defending. Believing.

Remember:

Anyone can manage tasks.
Real leaders develop people.
And you can't develop what you don't defend.

So choose wisely.
Your team is watching.
And they'll never forget.

Ô∏è Agree? Repost to share with your network.
 Followfor more on leadership.

Want my 80 best cheat sheets?
Get them here for free:

comments.commentText:
BONUS: 5 WAYS TO DEFEND YOUR TEAM WITHOUT LOWERING THE BAR 

1. Own mistakes publicly, correct them privately. If something goes wrong, take responsibility as a leader. But behind closed doors, help your team learn and improve without fear or shame.

2. Redirect blame, but share credit generously. When pressure comes from above, protect your team from unnecessary heat. But when wins happen, make sure their contributions; not just yours are recognized.

3. Push for fair workloads, not just fast results. Defending your team means speaking up when deadlines are unrealistic or workloads are unsustainable. Burnout isn‚Äôt a badge of honor; balance leads to better performance.

4. Call out toxic behavior, even when it's uncomfortable. Gossip, undercutting, or back channeling can destroy trust fast. Set the tone by addressing it directly, even when it comes from higher-ups.

5. Be the leader they trust in tough moments. Anyone can be supportive when things go well. True leadership shows when stakes are high; stay calm, stand by your team, and problem-solve together.

LET'S HEAR YOUR THOUGHTS

What‚Äôs one way a great leader has had your back?
Goncal R. That‚Äôs it. Trust and collaboration bring out the best in a team.

Now this one is really interesting. I‚Äôm sure opinions land on both sides of the debate.

Georgia state house is entertaining the idea that athletes
earning would be exempt from state income taxes.

The theory behind the push makes sense on its face: if other states are doing this, Georgia universities would be at a recruiting disadvantage. Furthermore, many NIL deals for athletes do not reach the scale of the
amounts that hit the headlines.

The counter-argument, however is that it makes a distinction between the same type of income- namely income from being an
, solely based on a criteria unrelated to the income itself. If you‚Äôre a student on an academic scholarship and get paid to post you have to pay state income taxes. Your best friend on the basketball team doesn‚Äôt. Could be the exact same post.

And what about those influencers that aren‚Äôt in college? What about other workers in the state that couldnt afford to go to college? Why are their earnings paying to subsidize others?

Lots to unpack here.

Monica Gauba
Monica Gauba
postsData.content:
For those embarking on developing AI agents, sharing a few lessons learned from our journey of developing vertical AI agents for GTM. 

Building these agents for developing GTM strategy and execution taught us that success starts with a clear breakdown of every task that we wanted the agent to perform and, more importantly, providing the right context for each.

**The foundation: A Solid Framework**

First we needed to build a robust framework. We began by designing a framework that not only outlines the different tasks for the agent, but also embeds the specific conditions needed for each one to execute effectively. The framework builds on best practices for GTM and also defines clear outcomes.

 **The Best Teacher? Testing.**

By running our agents through diverse scenarios‚Äîfrom building GTM strategies for different company sizes to various business types‚Äîwe uncovered gaps in our framework, issues with context delivery, and opportunities for better end user experience.

This testing process reinforced one key lesson: Crafting production-quality, reliable agents that can truly boost human productivity demands deep, iterative work.

Ô∏è The payoff?
The hard work pays off with smarter, more adaptable product that can genuinely support strategic decision-making.

However, the journey doesn't end after launch.

Supporting technology, like GenAI models are evolving everyday - with upgrades to APIs and newer models being released that require testing, enhancements and updates to all functional scenarios.

But the rewards in improved efficiency and effectiveness are mind blowing and well worth it.

 Takeaway:

Agent-driven software is the future‚Äîjust don't underestimate the work it takes to build products that people can rely on.

Updating AI agents with evolution of the underlying technology as well as evolution of business process they support will require deep, ongoing effort.

Stay adaptable. Keep iterating. The rewards in efficiency and impact are worth it.

**DM if you'd like to see what we've done and trade notes.**

comments.commentText: Also worth mentioning that as part of rapid experimentation and testing, leveraging A/B testing, shadow deployments and gradual rollouts before full deployments to assess impact can be applied.

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible insights! The importance of a solid framework and continuous testing cannot be overstated. Exciting times ahead for AI-driven solutions!

postsData.content:
This is how to get brand-new clients to treat you like an trusted friend... 

TL;DR = referrals, but....

There‚Äôs a way to ask and a time to ask. Get it wrong and they'll vanish.

Even worse, I‚Äôm getting feedback that people feel uncomfortable asking, or don‚Äôt know how.

How and when do you ask for them (if you do, and if not, curious why not)?

The cool thing about referrals is they come with built-in trust.

And we‚Äôre so used to giving referrals in our personal lives.

You know, the great movie you tell your friend about, or the restaurant you think everyone should try.

But, when it comes to business, we sometimes get shy or feel awkward, like it's too big an ask.

What‚Äôs your take on asking for referrals, or giving them?

I love being asked for referrals, and giving them.

I think I just like matchmaking and doing someone a good turn. It‚Äôs easy and it feels good. What‚Äôs your take?

comments.commentText: This is such a good question. There has to be a certain minimum of happy collaborations first. It has to be organic and can't be forced. It reminds me of... I think this is from Lean In (which I only read halfway because my eye started twitching, I have my issues with that book)--Sheryl Sandberg says you don't ask someone to be your mentor, you sort of organically develop a relationship and realize at some point that they've become your mentor. She says, "Instead of telling young people, "Get a mentor and you will excel," we tell them "Excel, and you will get a mentor." I feel like the same principle applies to referrals. Do excellent work and the referrals will follow. The timing of the ask is less important than the deep-down knowledge that the response will be "of course!"

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! It really is about timing and approach. I agree‚Äîreferrals create a win-win situation and strengthen our networks.

postsData.content:
It was a pleasure to be at the 32 HYSEA National Summit & Awards 2025, and to engage in a very grounded discussion with Sheenam Ohrie, Ranga Pothula, Mahesh Iyerandwho represented the broad spectrum of industry verticals that have leveraged the GCC model most effectively, and all at different stages in the GCC lifecycle.

As we discussed the much spoken of theme of "Operations to Innovation: Value Revolution @ GCCs", our focus was to demystify the cliched 'Value' term and we got into some details of:

- How is 'value' itself being defined: which is truly defined by the business impact being made
- What are the tailwinds enabling the evolution : where talent and technology top the list + global sponsorship and empowerment + the enabling ecosystem partners
- What are the headwinds to watch out for and mitigate : and most interestingly how the flipside of the very aspects that are your tailwinds could prove to be your headwinds if not managed well
- some interesting advice to the slew of young GCCs looking to establish their model to unlock value: aligning to the global business objectives, being agile and adpative, leveraging the ecosystem effectively, etc

It is the takeaways, industry insights and real, pragmatic examples of what is happening on the ground that make these discussions engaging and valuable- a big thank you to my panelists.

Logo Rank is an AI system that understands logo design. 

Trained on a million+ logo images, this AI tool can observe and critique the quality of a logo based on set parameters of - uniqueness, legibility, color/contrast, overall - and it is for free.

In the 'Uniqueness' measure, it can check if your design took inspiration from stock icons (a large portion of the images the system was trained on.)


While not a replacement for human review and discernment (the AI even points this out in the Overall segment), it can be another simple tool to help review your brand design with an AI 'eye' on the subject.

For my try, I used the logo I devised for AI LAB.

Too many leaders believe their job is to give answers. The truth? Your real power is in the questions you ask.

Matthew Archer
Matthew Archer
postsData.content:
Corporate America is trapped in the great meeting lie: 

We mistake talking for progress.

We sit in a glass-walled conference room, nodding at slides, rehashing old ideas, adding our two cents‚Ä¶ and somehow, we convince ourselves this is work.

It‚Äôs not.

Real work produces movement.
Real work creates clarity.
Real work solves problems.

But most meetings do none of these things. Instead, we:

 Keep stacking meetings on top of meetings, like a Jenga tower of wasted time.
 Add more attendees so no one feels left out‚Äîbut fewer people feel responsible.
 Spend more time debating who owns what than actually doing the work.

The result? An echo chamber of inefficiency.

 Employees spend an average of 31 hours a month in meetings they rate as unproductive.
 Companies lose $25,000 per employee per year due to bad meetings.
 And the worst part? No one stops the cycle.

We know meetings are broken, but we keep showing up, performing our roles, and booking the next one.

The fix isn‚Äôt better scheduling. It‚Äôs fundamental change.

 If a meeting doesn‚Äôt lead to a decision, it shouldn‚Äôt be on the calendar.
 If no one is accountable, no one should be there.
 If the loudest voice always wins, the best ideas are being lost.

Talking feels like progress. But progress only happens when decisions turn into action.

What‚Äôs one thing you‚Äôve done to break the cycle of useless meetings?

comments.commentText: Completely agree! I've recently been in 3 meetings that went in circles creating lists of To-Dos only to come to the next meeting with the same list... almost no progress was made. Very frustrating!

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! To combat this, Ive started implementing clear action items at the end of each meeting, ensuring accountability and real progress.

Salespeople‚Ä¶ Watch me book a meeting with a head of sales on a LIVE cold call below. 


While yes, I did book the meeting - there‚Äôs always room for improvement. Here is the good AND the bad from the call.

The GOOD:

1. Got him to visit the website.

One of the most unique aspects aboutis that you can live video call prospects on your website. The fact that I was able to show him this on the initial cold call, is a perfect way to build intrigue to ensure that he actually shows up to the meeting.

2. Calm and collected tone.

I think this call was a good example of how important it is to have a calm and collected tone to disarm prospects and show them you‚Äôre a real HUMAN - not some sleazy telemarketer.

3. ASKED for the meeting when I knew he was interested.

So often reps will wait TOO long to ask for the meeting - even when the prospect is clearly interested. I think I asked for the meeting at the perfect time during this call in particular.

The BAD:

1. Could have probed for more pain.

Definitely could have led with more pain to ensure there was a real problem to be solved.


All in all, I‚Äôd consider this a pretty successful cold call.

Cloud storage has often been overlooked as an area of waste and poor optimization, but it can have a huge impact on cloud spend and DevOps‚Äô time. Lucidity has set out to change that.

Available across AWS, Azure and Google Cloud, Lucidity gives cloud and DevOps teams the power to eliminate storage over-provisioning, the risk of downtime, and manual storage management efforts, helping them reduce costs by up to 70%.

As we ramp up the rocket ship, we‚Äôre thankful for our amazing team, customers, investors, and partners who have been with us so far. This is only the beginning for Lucidity and there is so much happening under the hood that we're excited about, so stay tuned and come see what we're building.

Create a vision for the life you really want - then work relentlessly towards making it a reality.

This is something I live by.

When I decided to rebrand SickFitness last year, I didn‚Äôt jump straight into the work.
I spent months solely focused on creating a vision for the life I wanted.

I asked myself:

Ô∏è What do I want for myself and my family in the future?
Ô∏è What does that future look like?
Ô∏è How can I design my business around the life I desire for myself, my wife, and my stepdaughter?
Ô∏è How do all of these things fit together?

I saw myself in the future and engraved that snapshot in my mind.

It took time - months of deep thinking and refining my vision - but once I had clarity, everything changed.

 No more waking up and going through the motions.
 No more aimless effort without direction.
 A clear vision became my blueprint.

It gave structure to my days, helped me set short-term and long-term goals, and aligned my daily actions with my ultimate purpose.

Once you have a vision and a plan, the next step is execution.

Put in the work EVERY single day. No matter how you feel.

Whether it‚Äôs your career, your fitness, or any other goal in life -
Have a vision for where you want to go.

Let your vision be your destination.
Let your plan be the roadmap.
Then show up and execute.

If you struggle to create a clear vision for your health and fitness goals, I‚Äôm here to help.

With over 20 years as a strength and conditioning specialist, I‚Äôve helped over a thousand people design their roadmap for success. Let‚Äôs build yours.

 Visit. You're capable of so much more than you think.

Struggling to Lead Your Team? Here‚Äôs Step 2!  

Great leadership isn‚Äôt just about giving direction, it‚Äôs about understanding the people you‚Äôre leading. 
Do you really know your team? Not just their skills, but what drives them, what motivates them, and how they think?

 Why this matters:
 It helps you leverage strengths instead of fighting against them.
 It allows you to motivate effectively based on what actually drives people.
 It transforms your team from a group of individuals into a high-performance unit.

Great teams don‚Äôt just happen, they are built by leaders who take the time to understand the people within them.

 Question for you: What‚Äôs the best way you‚Äôve found to understand your team‚Äôs motivations? Drop your thoughts below!

comments.commentText: When I first stepped into leadership, I focused only on skills and execution‚Äîbig mistake. It didn‚Äôt take long to realize that even the most skilled people won‚Äôt perform at their best if they don‚Äôt feel understood. Some thrive on recognition, others on challenges, and some just need autonomy to excel. But if you lead everyone the same way, you‚Äôll lose engagement, create frustration, and lower morale. Leadership isn‚Äôt about changing people‚Äîit‚Äôs about understanding who they are and positioning them for success.

Rustam Burkeev That‚Äôs such a powerful realization!  The best leaders evolve from managing tasks to understanding people, and that shift changes everything. When leaders take the time to recognize individual motivators, they don‚Äôt just improve performance; they create an environment where people feel valued, heard, and empowered. It‚Äôs not about one-size-fits-all leadership, but about meeting people where they are and helping them thrive in their own way. Your insight is spot on‚Äîleadership isn‚Äôt about changing people, it‚Äôs about leveraging their strengths to build something greater together.  Curious‚Äîwhat was the turning point that made you realize this in your leadership journey?

I once had a manager who couldn‚Äôt figure out why our team was underperforming, despite being highly skilled. The problem? He assigned work based on skills, not motivation. Once we shifted responsibilities based on individual strengths and motivators, our productivity skyrocketed. Lesson learned: Leadership isn‚Äôt just about execution‚Äîit‚Äôs about energy alignment.

Jonathan Tetlak Love the phrase: Energy Alignment! a very interesting take on how we should view 
#leadership

postsData.content:
Beware of Fake Job Posts on LinkedIn! 

Lately, I‚Äôve come across several fake pages posting job openings that don‚Äôt actually exist. What‚Äôs even more concerning is that these pages seem to be connected, as they constantly comment on each other‚Äôs posts and artificially boost their follower count.

A common pattern I‚Äôve noticed is that these pages never provide direct links to official company job postings. Instead, they redirect users to third-party platforms like Foundit or Unstop (which don‚Äôt even lead to the actual job postings but rather prompt users to create a profile on those platforms for every job link). This raises doubts about their legitimacy. Their goal seems to be engagement farming rather than genuinely helping job seekers.

It‚Äôs alarming that Linkedin's system is allowing such fake accounts to grow unchecked. These scams not only waste people‚Äôs time but also create false hope for those genuinely looking for opportunities.

If you‚Äôre job hunting, please be cautious! Always verify job postings by checking the official company website or trusted sources before applying. Also, avoid clicking on random external links shared by unfamiliar pages.

Has anyone else noticed this trend?

DataFrames and Datasets come with built-in optimization modules, thanks to the Catalyst optimizer and Tungsten project. They provide better performance compared to RDDs.

Use Kryo serialization instead of Java serialization. Kryo is faster and more compact, offering up to 10x better performance.

3Ô∏è‚É£ . ùóîùòÉùóºùó∂ùó± ùó¶ùóµùòÇùó≥ùó≥ùóπùó∂ùóªùó¥

Minimize shuffling by using operations like `mapPartitions()` instead of `map()`, and `coalesce()` instead of `repartition()`.

4Ô∏è‚É£ . ùóñùóÆùó∞ùóµùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùóÆùóªùó± ùó£ùó≤ùóøùòÄùó∂ùòÄùòÅùó≤ùóªùó∞ùó≤

Cache frequently accessed data using `cache()` or `persist()` methods to reduce computation time and improve performance.

5Ô∏è‚É£ . ùó¢ùóΩùòÅùó∂ùó∫ùó∂ùòáùó≤ ùóùùóºùó∂ùóªùòÄ

6Ô∏è‚É£ . ùóßùòÇùóªùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùó¶ùóΩùóÆùóøùó∏ ùóñùóºùóªùó≥ùó∂ùó¥ùòÇùóøùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ

Adjust executor memory, cores, and other configurations based on your workload. Proper tuning can lead to better resource utilization and performance.

7Ô∏è‚É£ . ùó®ùòÄùó≤ ùóïùòÇùó∂ùóπùòÅ-ùó∂ùóª ùóôùòÇùóªùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ

Leverage Spark's built-in functions instead of writing custom UDFs (User Defined Functions). Built-in functions are optimized and perform better.

8Ô∏è‚É£ . ùó£ùóÆùóøùòÅùó∂ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùó∂ùóªùó¥

Optimize data partitioning to ensure even distribution of data across nodes. This helps in parallel processing and reduces data skew.

9Ô∏è‚É£ . ùóîùòÉùóºùó∂ùó± ùó™ùó∂ùó±ùó≤ ùóßùóøùóÆùóªùòÄùó≥ùóºùóøùó∫ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóªùòÄ
Minimize the use of wide transformations like `groupByKey()` and `reduceByKey()`, which can cause shuffling and slow down your job.

 . ùó†ùóºùóªùó∂ùòÅùóºùóø ùóÆùóªùó± ùóßùòÇùóªùó≤

8 Habits of Consistent High Achievers

Small changes, massive results.

Thanks to my friend Mike Leber for this inspiring post!
(Be sure to follow him)

Bold moves spark progress,
But consistency creates lasting impact.

High achievers never rely on luck.
Instead, they master small habits that fuel massive growth.

These achievers intentionally build powerful routines.

Here are 8 daily practices that drive their success and can drive yours too:

1. Morning Focus
‚Ü≥ Start the day with clarity and intention.
‚Ü≥ Purpose fuels peak performance.

2. Focused Task Lists
‚Ü≥ Only what moves the needle.
‚Ü≥ Saying no is the secret to great results.

3. Regular Skill Growth
‚Ü≥ Never stop learning - curiosity is your superpower.
‚Ü≥ Continuous growth is the ultimate competitive advantage.

4. Planned Downtime
‚Ü≥ Constantly recharge yourself.
‚Ü≥ Rest isn't a luxury, it's a necessity.

5. Smart Delegation
‚Ü≥ Share the workload.
‚Ü≥ Empowering your team multiplies your impact.

6. Continuous Networking
‚Ü≥ Relationships are the rocket fuel of success.
‚Ü≥ Strong networks create endless opportunities.

7. Evening Review
‚Ü≥ Reflect and evaluate your progress daily.
‚Ü≥ Self-awareness is the foundation of growth.

8. Regular Feedback
‚Ü≥ Seek feedback from peers, mentors, and clients.
‚Ü≥ Authentic feedback fuels rapid development.

Success isn't about one-time moves.

It's built on simple habits others overlook.

Start small - results will follow.

I'm focusing on #6 as my daily habit.

Which habit will you focus on first?

postsData.content:
Before you hire that marketing agency, ask this question first: Could your business actually handle an influx of qualified leads right now?

I've seen it countless times - businesses invest heavily in marketing without having the foundation to convert and serve those leads. It's like trying to fill a bucket with holes.

What good are 200 leads if you can only handle 50? Growth should be sustainable, not overwhelming.

Ask yourself:
‚Ä¢ Is your sales process documented?
‚Ä¢ Do you have enough staff?
‚Ä¢ Can you maintain quality at scale?
‚Ä¢ Are your systems ready?

Save this post for when you're ready to scale!

Hard truths -- Better to find them, than have the hard truth find you.

Create a vision for the life you really want - then work relentlessly towards making it a reality.

This is something I live by.

When I decided to rebrand SickFitness last year, I didn‚Äôt jump straight into the work.
I spent months solely focused on creating a vision for the life I wanted.

I asked myself:

Ô∏è What do I want for myself and my family in the future?
Ô∏è What does that future look like?
Ô∏è How can I design my business around the life I desire for myself, my wife, and my stepdaughter?
Ô∏è How do all of these things fit together?

I saw myself in the future and engraved that snapshot in my mind.

It took time - months of deep thinking and refining my vision - but once I had clarity, everything changed.

 No more waking up and going through the motions.
 No more aimless effort without direction.
 A clear vision became my blueprint.

It gave structure to my days, helped me set short-term and long-term goals, and aligned my daily actions with my ultimate purpose.

Once you have a vision and a plan, the next step is execution.

Put in the work EVERY single day. No matter how you feel.

Whether it‚Äôs your career, your fitness, or any other goal in life -
Have a vision for where you want to go.

Let your vision be your destination.
Let your plan be the roadmap.
Then show up and execute.

This isn't the sexiest part of a job search, but it'll make you LOOK it. Adopt the lazy genius way to make it easy.

What am I talking about?

 Company Research.

Be genius about what matters and lazy about what doesn't  That's the motto of Kendra Adachi's 2020 read, The Lazy Genius Way.

A targeted job search is an effective one. One important tool in your toolkit is a target company list.

Doing this research work sets up your job search strategy and gives you the gems for impactful convos. Because when the time comes for interviews and networking meetings, you'll know what's trending and the pain points (and wins) of your company of interest.
